name: 15 Restaurants for Laid Back Squad Dinners

text.text: 15 Restaurants for Laid Back Squad Dinners

Your squad WhatsApp group has been popping off all afternoon and the gang is clamouring for a meet up. After finally blocking out an evening when everyone is free, you've found yourself with the job of booking dinner.

Now you must source a friendly sort of restaurant where loud voices won't receive raised eyebrows, whilst also providing for full time foodies looking to load up on social clout. Lucky you've got us doing the work for you, eh?

tip.text:
Forza Win is a shape shifter. What started out as a roaming pop up soon found a permanent home in a restored old grain store in Copeland Park, where it then morphed into a sumptuous set-menu affair. These days, it's a humble restaurant serving simple(ish) Italian dishes, with a modest price point to match - but don't underestimate the magic going on in the kitchen: the flavours here are devastatingly good.

Whilst the menu changes frequently, you'll always find an array of pasta dishes alongside some choice meat (and the odd veggie) mains. We slurped up tagliatelle topped with oven-blistered tomatoes that burst with sun-drenched flavours, as well as a sausage pappardelle that had the comfort factor and flavour of bangers and mash. Dessert is serious affair: opt for the custardo (a Forza Win invention - espresso topped with cr√®me anglaise) and their deconstructed tiramisu, then prepare to nurture a food baby for the eve. Bop along on Wednesdays for their 'Awesome Sauce' deal, where you can scoop up a pasta dish and a glass of booze for a tenner.

text.text: This restored grain store in Copeland Park makes a perfect backdrop for the devastatingly good flavours of Forza Win. Italian-inspired dishes burst with sun-drenched flavours, fresh pastas and seasonal veg - and all at a pleasingly modest price point too. Bop along on Wednesdays for their 'Awesome Sauce' deal, where you can scoop up a pasta dish and a glass of booze for a tenner.

tip.text:
You'll find Berber & Q tucked away in the railway arches in Haggerston, grilling up lip smacking Middle Eastern delicacies that have garnered lots of diehard fans. The cavernous space throbs with techno music, flickering candle light and a distinctly East London vibe.

Expect big Levantine flavours, with equal attention given to both meat and veggie dishes; go for succulent grilled meats, or their cult cauliflower shawarma - doused in tahini and rose, it packs some seriously delightful smoky and sweet flavours. Midday munchers can opt for their gigantic full Israeli platter, complete with hummus, honeyed feta, roasted beets, dak dak salad and enough trimmings to put you in a mild food coma.

text.text: You'll find Berber & Q tucked away under the arches behind Haggerston station, grilling up lip smacking Middle Eastern delicacies that have garnered lots of diehard fans. Go for their trays of succulent grilled meats - their beef adana kofte with chilli and garlic sauce and lamb shawarma make us feel some type of way - and stock up on cocktails.

tip.text:
If you're not familiar with the Puglian region of Italy, Ostuni is a damn good place to start. Specialising in the food and wine from the 'boot heel' of Italy, you're guaranteed lots of wood-fired meat, fresh seafood, and full-bodied wines. That's a combo that pulls us in, make no mistake.

The interior has been kitted out to feel like a Puglia piazza too ‚Äì lots of exposed whitewashed stone and simple tables makes it feel nice and informal, and helps you forget that the weather outside is probably rather shit.

text.text: Specialising in the food and wine from the 'boot heel' of Italy, you're guaranteed lots of wood-fired meat, fresh seafood and full-bodied wines. The interior has been kitted out to feel like a Puglia piazza too - lots of exposed whitewashed stone and simple tables makes it feel nice and informal, ideal for getting the gang together.

tip.text:
Carl Clarke, aka the chef turned DJ behind God Save the Clam, Rock Lobsta and Disco Bistro is famous for his burgers and seafood. Now he's turning his hand to fried chicken and wait for it...sour cocktails.

This unlikely combination is the perfect answer to those late night cravings. We'd recommend starting off with a little szechuan aubergine, then working your way through the crispiest, tastiest chicken in town. Big dogs will be tempted to order the whole fried chicken but smaller bites are just as good especially when paired with zingers like ginger miso slaw, pickled watermelon or hot-and-sour pineapple. And to drink? Sours of course!

text.text: There's something undeniable about the combination of fried chicken and sour cocktails - it's pretty mouthwatering stuff. Perfect fodder for late night cravings and getting a little messy with da boiz. We'd recommend starting off with a little Szechuan aubergine, then working your way through the crispiest, tastiest chicken in town.

tip.text:
Time to come over all Tony Soprano at Ciao Bella: a buzzy place of unadulterated, carb-loaded Italian goodness. Going strong for 30 years now, you get the sense that this place hasn't changed much/at all; which is really its charm. Blunt old-timer waiters grunt about the place, a resident pianist flexes his fingers now and again, and old movie posters and black and white pictures cover every inch of wall.

But let's talk food and the huge menu full of flavoursome, generously-sized favourites: big and tasty 12" pizzas, insane portions of rich pasta every which way, and hefty meat and fish dishes. Whatever you get, you'll likely be needing an extra large doggie bag or a stretcher to take your happy, bloated body out of this Italo original. Just don't forget to have a sip of limoncello as you're carried out.

text.text: Time to come over all Tony Soprano at Ciao Bella: a buzzy place of unadulterated, carb-loaded Italian goodness. Going strong for 30 years now, we keep coming back for the old-timer waiters, 12" pizzas, insane portions of spag' bol' and a complimentary shot of limoncello on your way out. That's Italian hospitality for you.

tip.text:
If you're in need of a little something extra to get your morning well and truly off the rocks, go nuts and swap your morning latte for an espresso martini over at Caravan. Their coffee is roasted on-site daily to extract the freshest flavour and special focus is payed to sourcing sustainably.

Coffee and cocktails are not the only things these kids are good at either, come throughout the day and well into the evening for some truly delicious sharing plates, think Mocilla (black pudding) hash with pickled cucumbers; herby, spicy lamb meatball flat breads; and an oxtail chaat masala that'll have you crying in sheer ecstasy... Ok maybe not, but it is very tasty. Pricey doe.

text.text: Set in the huge King's Cross development, this Caravan is full of the hustle and bustle of its area. Apart from the handy location, high ceilings, long tables and plenty of sharing pizzas and small plates make this an ideal spot for meeting pals. Not to mention all the hidden wonders and original sups on their cocktail list.

tip.text:
On the back streets of Tokyo, yakitori joints are a given. In these often cramped and pokey street huts, people gather to share a beer and chow down on grilled skewers. Named after a particular free range chicken in Japan, Jidori brings you a little taste of the homeland in the form of delicious (and free range) chicken skewers and small plates: think chicken liver, thigh, breast or broth.

There's even an omakase tasting menu where each dish showcases a different part of the bird. They're so serious about chicken they've got a master stock that's been running for years, that flavours everything with its gorgeous richness. Our winner was the minced chicken skewer dipped in cured egg yolk - actual heaven on a stick. We finished with the understandably popular ginger ice cream with miso caramel, topped with sweet potato crisps, and left smiling. They even have a tasty all vegan menu too.

Also worth noting there's a set karaoke menu for ¬£40 a head (including karaoke in a private room). You might know someone who's partial to that sort of thing... like us.

text.text: We could spend all day singing Jidori's praises, discussing the handy Covent Garden location, their delicious and mighty reasonably priced rice bowls and pure yakitori skills; but then we wouldn't have time to get into the astonishing karaoke deal: ¬£40 a head for a private room, set menu and four hours of singing your heart out. It truly is the stuff of dreams.

tip.text:
Do you sometimes wish you were Rick Stein on a culinary tour of the Mediterranean coast? Well you're not. But here's the next best thing: a charming bistro at the bottom of Broadway Market that seems to take all the best flavours from Spain, Italy, Greece and Turkey and compile them on one manageable, delicious menu.

It's an ambient spot, filled with overhanging greenery, gentle lighting and a soundtrack that occasionally drifts into Euro-pop. Like being on holiday somewhere sunny, but with nice food. Here are some things you absolutely must eat: the Picos blue and date croquetas; the octopus with hummus and cumin yoghurt; and the free range chicken thigh with honey poached apricots, sumac yoghurt and pistachios. And then end things with a deconstructed baklava with almonds, whipped cream and mango. 'Glorious' you say to yourself, as the camera pans out to reveal Regent's Canal.

text.text: This charming bistro at the bottom of Broadway Market seems to take all the best flavours from Spain, Italy, Greece and Turkey and compile them on one manageable, delicious menu. It's an ambient spot, filled with overhanging greenery, gentle lighting and a soundtrack that occasionally drifts into Euro-pop... Just the ticket for galz dinner.

tip.text:
It's round two for Hoppers, with all the same moreish goods but in a larger, more bookable venue - hooray! You've got two floors to plonk your arse on; an upstairs that's all white walls and lovely foliage, and a downstairs complete with dark wood, alcoves and an open kitchen. Get the juices flowing with an arrack cocktail (it's strong stuff) and settle in for some mad good flavours.

The scrummy hoppers are still very much on the cards here - fermented rice and coconut pancake bowls, eaten with chutneys and sambols. You'd also do well to try the banana leaf roasted sea bream with green mango and madras onion sambol. If you're heading in a big group you can avoid all the 'Oooh shall we share?' by ordering the 'feast'. They basically choose all the good stuff (veggie or meaty) and lay it out for ya.

text.text: We went potty when Hoppers first opened in Covent Garden - people were queuing up for hours waiting for those crispy hoppers filled with all manner of hearty curries, chutneys and sambols - it was a glorious time to be alive. Then a second (and 100% more bookable) venue opened on St Christopher's Place and we were chuffed to bits.

tip.text:
Know Ben Chapman? Well you should. He's the mighty talented chef behind Soho favourite and spice paradise Kiln. Smoking Goat has a more relaxed vibe, taking inspo from the quick snacks and comfort food served in the late-night Bangkok canteens. Flavours are sour and spicy, though not quite Kiln levels and cocktails are appropriately simple and refreshing.

Smoking Goat may not be a showstopper but it's the perfect spot for a squad dinner. In an ideal world you'll go in a group of four or so, you'll order a couple beers, the barbecued goat and turmeric massaman curry, and some sides (we're thinking kale, sambal aubergine and lardo fried rice). You'll scoff the lot then leave plenty full with change from a ¬£20 note. Unless you want to make your own decisions, in which case you should get off this app, mate.

text.text: Taking inspo from the quick snacks and comfort food served in the late-night Bangkok canteens, Smoking Goat has a relaxed hubbub perfect for Shoreditch goers. Flavours are sour and spicy - balanced by simple and refreshing cocktails. Order a couple beers, grab the sharing portion barbecued goat and turmeric massaman curry, a few sides and Bob's your uncle.

tip.text:
It's not like London needed any more informal fresh pasta bars, and yet, here we are, dreaming of Pastaio. Also, they definitely have a leg up on the competition for being so darn reasonable. You could easily just grab a ridiculously decadent fried mozzarella, 'nduja and honey sandwich for a fiver, but we sat down and took our time over bowls of pure creamy joy.

If you're in need of a real carb hit, nothing will beat the comforting power of the cacio e pepe, homemade bucatini pasta with the perfect bouncy bite, pepper and oodles of creamy cheese. We‚Äôd recommend balancing it with one of their fresh seasonal salads - ours was a watermelon and feta number, livened up with yellow tomatoes and mint. Pick something simple from the short wine list and finish with one of their homemade cellos - like limoncello, but in different seasonal flavours. It's a buzzy, fast-paced spot, with loud music and prosecco slushies, so keep it up your sleeve for a slightly rowdier dinner.

text.text: It's not like London needed any more informal fresh pasta bars, and yet, here we are, dreaming of Pastaio. Their creamy pasta, seasonal salads and tasty smalls plates are all pretty reasonable too. It's a buzzy, fast-paced spot, with loud music and prosecco slushies - so it's unlikely you'll offend any old biddies with sordid tales of dates gone right.

tip.text:
What‚Äôs the best thing you can do with ¬£8? If you‚Äôve answered, ‚Äògo to FM Mangal on Camberwell Church Street and get the lamb shish box meal‚Äô, then you‚Äôve got it right. FM Mangal is, for our money, the best kebabby to be found in South: a typical no-frills Turkish joint where the sweet elixir of smoking coals charring meat to perfection wafts out the door and brings in any local with an interest in good food.

The tender meat here comes with dope company: fragrant rice, fresh salad, charred flat breads, pomegranate molasses and complimentary charcoal-grilled onions in a sweet and sour vinegary sauce. Served up by a lovely staff, you‚Äôre not getting tablecloths or airs and graces; you're getting an ideal bite when you can't be arsed to cook or a venue for a lively group dine out.

text.text: FM Mangal is, for our money, the best kebabby to be found in South: a typical no-frills Turkish joint where the sweet elixir of smoking coals charring meat to perfection wafts out the door and brings in any local with an interest in good food. Served up by a lovely staff, you‚Äôre not getting tablecloths or any airs and graces here - just a bloody good dinner.

tip.text:
Stockwell Continental has that relaxed modern pizzeria vibe which we've become so accustomed to in London - which is no bad thing. The drinks list is simple, decor is minimal, and the menu - a short list of absolute bangers.

It's all about Roman-style pizza here, which is crisper than the fluffy, chewy Neapolitan we've become accustomed to at Franco Manca. And the toppings? They're ingredient led with all sorts of quality Italian imports, and most importantly, they go right up to the edge, baby. We hoovered up the ‚Äònduja with rocket and pickled red onion; and mortadella with ricotta and pickled chilli.

Service is real easy going and slightly battered floor tiles add to our romantic idea of a Roman pizzeria. You can grab a seat at the marble bar, and watch the good pizza lord at work, but we were comfier on the grown up table, sippin' on Aperol spritz. If you're too much of a snob for that lurid orange glow, there's martinis, negronis and a tidy Italian wine list too - all pretty reliable stuff if you ask us.

text.text: Sporting the relaxed modern pizzeria vibe, Stockwell Continental offers minimal decor, prosecco on tap and a short menu of absolute bangers. It's all about Roman-style pizza here, which is crisper than the fluffy, chewy Neapolitan we've become accustomed to. Ingredients are high qual', staff are the friendly sort and cocktails are all Italian baby.

tip.text:
Bao's Soho spot had people queueing out the door when it opened a few years back (and actually still does). That's why knowing you can book a table at this Fitzrovia spot is pretty tidy - especially considering how delectable their foodie offerings are. Their steamed milk bao buns are filled with all kinds of sultry concoctions - like a sticky pork classic, a tangy turnip number and our favourite - the heavenly tasting black cod. There's a load of other good stuff up for grabs too, including an adventurous pig blood cake.

Set across two exceedingly stylish floors you can choose to sit downstairs by the open kitchen or upstairs watching bar tenders make all sorts of smooth, and grown-up tasting cocky Ts.

text.text: Unlike the Soho branch, you can book this baby for a night of milk-steamed buns, sticky concoctions and crisp cocktails. Set across two exceedingly stylish floors, Bao's ground floor is often filled with dating couples, while the basement just has space for one large group - just in sight of the awe-inducing open kitchen.

tip.text:
The Good Egg in Stokey is up there as one of our fave London spots, and now Soho's Kingly Court complex gets a piece of the action. It's an all day dining kind of place, but if you're there for brunch, you're nailing it. Why? Because there is no better way to brunch than with Jewish inspired comfort food and classic American cocktails. Wrap your lips around their sabich - a sarnie made with fried aubergines, mango sauce, pickles and a green herb sauce (zhoug) - and wash it down with an espresso martini with homemade cardamom syrup and green pistachio.

Time your visit just right and you'll smell the homemade Jewish bakes - like challah (milk bread), proper Israeli-style pitta, and their epic chocolate babka. Aaah, the promised land.

text.text: The Good Egg's Kingly Court branch is an all day dining kind of place, where brunch is fire and dinner is similarly not to shabby. Think Jewish-inspired comfort food and classic American cocktails. Share tasty dips, sticky meats and veggie small plates - and whatever you do, don't leave without a taste of the za'atar fried chicken.
